item.title: [WIP] Workout Protocol for Beginners
item.description:
A lot of my friends keep asking me the same basic questions again and again, hence this article.
Here’s my updated workout split, if you’re here for just that.

Introduction

The goal of this article is to impart basic knowledge and roadmap for beginners who wish to get bigger and stronger but don’t know where to start.

1.1 Terminology for Dummies
1.2 Terminology
1.3 Why Workout?
1.4 Quickstart

item.title: 1.1 Terminology for Dummies
item.description:
Really common vocabulary that gym goers use.

Gym

A place of physical wellbeing. One could use this to pursue various goals such as more muscle mass or strength, cardiovascular strength, plyometrics, sports like crossfit, or health in general to name a few. In this article, we’ll only be discussing the size and strength aspect of it.

Reps / Repetitions

The number of times you perform a movement at once. For example, 10 reps of bicep curl.

item.title: 1.2 Terminology
item.description:
Techincal but common words gym goers use.

Hypertrophy

A fancy word for muscle bulding.

Compound Movement

Any lift that involves two or more joints. Typically accompanied with two or more muscle groups being involved. Example, dips (chest, tricep, and front delt).

Isolation Movement

Only one joint is involved in the movement, usually accompanied with just one muscle. Example, tricep pushdown (tricep)

Progressive Overload

Increase in weights over time, to get the same stimulus for growth.

item.title: 1.3 Why Workout?
item.description:
Before we even begin to dive into the article, we gotta ask ourselves

Why should we even workout to begin with?

Here are a few generic but solid reasons why you could consider working out.

You’ll feel stronger and more capable and empowered
You’ll age slower
You’ll think better
Not to mention you will also become more attractive
And it is an indication that you’re a dedicated and commited person

item.title: 1.4 Quickstart
item.description:
Introduction

As a newcomer to lifting weights, the first goal should be to learn and get good at the basic movement patterns.

  • Pulling
    • A Vertical Pull (like Pullups)
    • A Horizontal Pull or a Row (like Barbell Rows)
  • Pushing
    • A Horizontal Push (like Pushups)
    • An Overhead Press (like standing barbell overhead press).
  • Legs
    • A Squat Pattern
    • A Hip-Hinge (like Deadlifts)

Most people just wanna look good and feel strong, just getting stronger at the basics along with some isolation work should do that.

item.title: 2.1 Basic Muscle Science
item.description:
Introduction

This section dives into various big muscles we have that we need to focus on.
I’ll categorise muscles and movement patterns in terms of PUSH PULL and LEGS, so that it’s easier to follow.

  • Push
    • Chest
    • Front Delt
    • Tricep
  • Pull
    • Back
    • Bicep
    • Rear Delt
  • Legs
    • Quads
    • Hams
    • Glutes
    • Calves

Push

The musculature involved in pushing stuff away from us.
For Example, in Bench Press, you’re pressing/pushing the barbell away from yourself.
The following muscles are part of the pushing musclature:

item.title: 2.2 Functions of different Musculatures
item.description:
Introduction

This section explores how to train a muscle group based on its functions.

  • Push
    • Chest
    • Front Delt
    • Tricep
  • Pull
    • Back
    • Bicep
    • Rear Delt
  • Legs
    • Quads
    • Hams
    • Glutes
    • Calves

Chest

The Main function of the chest is to press.

Chest Press

Movements like the barbell bench press, dips etc come over here, where we’re pressing the weight using our chest muscles.
Getting stronger at these builds the majority of the chest.

item.title: 2.3 What builds muscle?
item.description:
Now that I’ve familiarized you with most of the basics concepts of training for hypertrophy, it’s time to realize what actually builds muscle.

What actually build muscle?

Training a muscle for it’s function under mechanical load and tension till muscular failure gives a stimulus for growth.
The protein and calories we consume is used to synthesize muscle, aided with with good sleep and recovery.

Essentially, we are breaking down the muscle fibres when we work out, and building it back when we eat and sleep, to slightly bigger size than before.
This repeated again and again over a period of months/years is what gives significant visible change in one’s physique.

item.title: 3.1 Daily Recommendations
item.description:
In Works

Consume > 1.6 x (Bodyweight in KGs) protein For example, I am 70 kg, so I should consume 1.6 x 70 ~ 112 g protein.

For calories, calculate your maintenance here and eat in a slight surplus (100~200 cal). Never be in a deficit as a beginner. But always fill your calories with clean food.
No need to track carbs and fat also, just make you’re well fed and energized before a workout.

item.title: 3.2 How to complete protein
item.description:
In Works

I’ve written this from the perspective of a student, with a limited budget.

The most cost efficient and complete protein source will be eggs. I cosume 10 eggs everyday which give me around ~60g and costs me 100 rs.
The rest is done using chicken and soya chunks. I personally have a tiffin service which is where I get my chicken from and costs me ~200/day and gives around 40g protein, but you can do it cheaper. And soya chunks are cheap to begin with.

item.title: 4.1 Sleep
item.description:
In Works

7+ hours sleep preferable before 12 am and at the same time everyday.

item.title: Why Deepseek is better than ChatGPT
item.description:
Why DeepSeek Is Better Than ChatGPT: A Comprehensive Analysis

In the rapidly evolving world of artificial intelligence, language models like ChatGPT have made significant strides in natural language processing, enabling machines to generate human-like text and engage in meaningful conversations. However, as a more advanced iteration of AI, DeepSeek brings several key advantages that set it apart from ChatGPT. Here’s why DeepSeek is better:

1. Enhanced Contextual Understanding

While ChatGPT is impressive in its ability to generate coherent responses, DeepSeek is designed with a deeper understanding of context. It can maintain longer and more complex conversations without losing track of the topic. This allows DeepSeek to provide more accurate and relevant responses, especially in nuanced or multi-layered discussions.

item.title: Workout
item.description:
I follow a push, pull, leg inspired split.
If you’re here to learn as a beginner, I’d redirect you to here.

Push (chest, biceps, front and side delts)

  • Seated DB Overhead Press ss Preacher Curl
  • Incline DB Press ss Preacher Curl
  • Lateral Raises SS Hammer curls
  • Hanging Knee Raises

No overhead pressing for now.

Pull (back, triceps, rear delt)

  • Neutral Grip Cable High Row / Conventional Deadlifts (alternate)
  • Neutral Grip Pulldown SS Skull Crushers
  • DB Rows
  • V-Bar Tricep Pushdown SS Reverse Pec Deck

Legs (quads, hamstrings)

  • Squats
  • Leg Curls
  • Obliques

No direct calf work, rather I try to get in ~10k steps everyday, which is the only cardio I do in a day.

item.title: Fix your attention span
item.description:
A summary to this video by @aevytv.

Why to fix attention?

The ability to focus, be creative, and being bored are innate to human beings and probably the very reasons they are powerful. If we lose our ability to channel our attention, we risk losing all these qualities that make us interesting and useful, and that’s no bueno.
It makes doing simple low dopamine tasks like reading books, going through an assignment, even working out a great challenge to push through.
Personally, I would like myself better if I’m more productive and consuming media consciously.

item.title: home
Movies & Shows
item.description:
I’d recommend everyone to watch these at least once in their lifetimes.

42 (2013)

added on 07 Feb, 2025

The story of the baseball legend Jackie Robinson’s journey starting out in the MLB, highlighting the racism in the sport. All the leads have done phenomenal acting, and this is a movie you won’t forget anytime soon.
Fun Fact - This is the movie that earned Chadwick Boseman his role as Black Panther, and rightfully so. May he rest in peace.

item.title: search
item.description:
<section id=search-bar>
	<input id=searchInput placeholder="Search with SearX" autocomplete=off />
</section>
<section id=cards>
	<button aria-label="send search query" onclick="search()" title="Search" class="ph-bold ph-magnifying-glass" id=searchButton></button>
	<button aria-label="cycle through the search engine" onclick="toggleEngine()" title="Toggle Engine" id=toggleButton class="ph-bold ph-arrow-arc-right"></button>
	<button aria-label="clear search input" onclick="clearInput()" title="Clear Input" id=clearButton class="ph-bold ph-backspace"></button>
</section>
<style>
#content {
	width: 40%;
	max-width: 400px;
	margin: auto;
}

#search-bar {
	display: flex;
	width: 100%;
	margin-bottom: 1em;
}

#searchInput {
	width: 100%;
	font: normal 450 1.2rem "Archivo", sans-serif;
	text-align: center;
	border-style: solid;
	border-width: 0 0 2px 0;
	filter: brightness(40%);
	padding: 0.9em;
	background: transparent;
	color: var(--clr-fg);
}

#searchInput:focus {
	filter: brightness(85%);
}

#cards {
	display: grid;
	margin: 1.5em auto;
	gap: 1em;
	grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr);
	width: 100%;
}

#cards button {
	text-align: center;
	padding: 1.1em 0;
	font-size: 1.1em;
	color: var(--fg);
	background: var(--clr-bg-alt);
}

#cards button:hover {
	filter: brightness(105%);
}

#cards button:active {
}

@media screen and (max-width: 10.6in) { #content { width: calc(100%); } }
</style>
<script>
const allEngines = [
	//{ name:"Google", preposition:"with", color:"hsl(355,75%,76%)", url:"google.com/search?q=", urlFilters:"" },
	{ name:"ArchWiki", preposition:"over", color:"#80A9A0", url:"wiki.archlinux.org/index.php?search=", urlFilters:"" },
	{ name:"SearX", preposition:"with", color:"#A9B665", url:"searx.be/search?q=", urlFilters:"" },
	{ name:"YouTube", preposition:"over", color:"#D87873", url:"youtube.com/results?search_query=", urlFilters:"" },
	{ name:"Github", preposition:"over", color:"#D8A657", url:"github.com/search?q=", urlFilters:"&s=stars" },
];

var activeEngine;
var x = -1;

function toggleEngine() {
	x = (x == allEngines.length - 1) ? -1:x; 
	x = x + 1;
	activeEngine = allEngines[x];
	document.getElementById('searchInput').placeholder = "Search " + activeEngine.preposition + " " + activeEngine.name;
	document.getElementById('searchInput').style.borderColor = activeEngine.color;
	document.getElementById('searchInput').focus();
}

function search() {
	let realVal = document.getElementById('searchInput').value.replace("%","%25").replace(/#/g,"%23").replace(/&/g,"%26").replaceAll("+","%2B").replace("/","%2F").replace("?","%3F").replace("=","%3d").replace("_","%5F").replace(/:/g,"%3A");
	let noSpaceVal = realVal.replace(/\s/g, "");
	{ if (noSpaceVal == "") {window.location.reload(false);}
		else {window.open("https://" + activeEngine.url + realVal + activeEngine.urlFilters, "_self");} };
}

function clearInput() {
	document.getElementById("searchInput").value = "";
	document.getElementById('searchInput').focus();
}

toggleEngine();
document.getElementById("searchInput").addEventListener("keydown", event =>
	{ if (event.key == "Enter") search(); // keycode 13
		else if (event.altKey && event.key == "Tab") toggleEngine(); // keycode 9
		else if (event.altKey && event.key == "c") clearInput();
	});
</script>
<script src=https://savar.is-a.dev/js/date.js></script>
